An inhaled medication that relaxes constricted air passages to make breathing easier

A spacer is a way of delivering the bronchodilator drugs effectively into the lungs. No child under 5 years should be given an inhaler without a spacer. A spacer works as well as a nebuliser if correctly used.
Spacers can be made in the following way
ONE: Use a 500ml drink bottle or similar
Cut a hole in the bottle base in the same shape as the mouthpiece of the inhaler.
This can be done using a sharp knife.
Cut the bottle between the upper quarter and the lower ¾ and disregard the upper quarter of the bottle.
Cut a small V in the border of the large open part of the bottle to fit to the child\'s nose and be used as a mask.
Flame the edge of the cut bottle with a candle or a lighter to soften it.
In a small baby, a mask can be made by making a similar hole in a plastic (not polystyrene) cup. Alternatively commercial spacers can be used if available.
TWO: To use an inhaler with a spacer
Remove the inhaler cap. Shake the inhaler well.
Insert mouthpiece of the inhaler through the hole in the bottle or plastic cup.

The child should put the opening of the bottle into his mouth and breath in and out through the mouth. A carer then presses down the inhaler and sprays into the bottle while the child continues to breath normally.
Wait for three to four breaths and repeat.
For younger children, place the cup over the child\'s mouth and use as a spacer in the same way.
If a spacer is being used for the first time, it should be primed by 4–5 extra puffs from the inhaler.
If a spacer is being used for the first time, it should be primed by 4–5 extra puffs from the inhaler before giving it to the child.
Chest Indrawing
The lower ribs on both sides of the chest are pulled in when the child breathes in, even when the child is not crying.
Select Mild if the ribs and area below the chest are retracting moderately.
Select Moderate if the above symptoms are present as well as flared nostrils or indrawing below the sternum (upper chest).
Select Severe if there are large retractions in the upper and lower chest areas as well as nostril flaring or grunting noises.
Pulse Oximeter
A device that measures the oxygen saturation of blood in a patient.

A device that measures the oxygen saturation of blood in a patient. This clip device may be used on an earlobe, across the bridge of the nose, in the mouth, on a toe, or on a fingertip. Normal levels are above 90 percent.
Improvise a Spacer
A spacer is a device that can improve the effectiveness of inhalers by allowing more of the steroids to be inhaled deeply into the lungs.

A spacer is a device that can improve the effectiveness of inhalers by allowing more of the steroids to be inhaled deeply into the lungs. If no spacers are available, they can be improvised using an empty plastic water bottle
Find an empty plastic water bottle and remove the cap.
Cut a hole into the bottom of the bottle in the same shape as the mouth of the inhaler.
Cut the bottle between the upper quarter and lower ¾ and throw away the upper part.
Soften the cut edge of the bottle with a lighter or candle flame.
Insert the inhaler into the bottom opening as shown in the image.
A mask can be made by following the above steps with a plastic cup.
Wheezing
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing
Listen to breathing with a stethoscope
Select Mild if the child wheezes somewhat when breathing out
Select Moderate if the child wheezes loudly when breathing out
Select Severe if the child is wheezing loudly breathing in and out and/or the breaths are very soft.
Inhaled Bronchodilator
An inhaled medication that relaxes constricted air passages to make breathing easier
Remove inhaler and spacer caps.
Shake inhaler for 5 seconds.
Insert inhaler into spacer.
If the spacer has never been used, prepare it with 4 puffs from the inhaler.
Put mask over nose and mouth with a good seal.
Press inhaler down once.
Breathe normally for 3 to 6 breaths to empty spacer. Slow your breathing if there is a whistle sound.
Remove mask from child’s face and wait 10 seconds
Shake inhaler then start with step 4 before each additional puff.
Wipe skin around child’s mouth with a wet cloth when done.
Reassess child in AT LEAST 10 minutes
Convulsions
Seizures, involuntary shaking movements of the body often caused by serious infections or high fever

A sudden, violent, irregular movement of a limb or of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles and associated especially with brain disorders such as epilepsy, the presence of certain toxins or other agents in the blood, or fever in children.
Diazepam
A medicine used to stop convulsions

Diazepam typically produces a calming effect. It is commonly used to treat a range of conditions including anxiety, alcohol withdrawal syndrome, muscle spasms, seizures, trouble sleeping, and restless legs syndrome. When given into a vein, effects begin in one to five minutes and last up to an hour. By mouth, effects may take 40 minutes to begin.
Pneumonia
Lung inflammation caused by bacterial or viral infection

Pneumonia is an inflammatory condition of the lung affecting primarily the small air sacs known as alveoli. Symptoms can include productive or dry cough, chest pain, fever, and trouble breathing. Severity is variable.
Unresponsive
A condition in which a person does not respond to questions, commands or painful stimuli
If a person or their body is unresponsive, they do not react physically in a normal way, or do not make any movements.
Stridor
A noise on breathing in due to obstruction of the upper airway
Stridor is a loud whistling sound made when taking in a breath. It is a sign of upper airway blockage and must be treated right away to prevent the airway from completely closing.
